abstract.p: Letter from Michael McGuffin (American Herbal Products Assn) challenges study that found no convincing proof to support use of St John's wort for treating depression

block.p: The director of the study that evaluated St. John's wort asserts that there is no convincing proof to support the botanical's use for any type of depression, though he acknowledges that other studies say it works (news article, April 18). Indeed, several well-designed clinical analyses have studied St. John's wort for its actions on mild to moderate depression and have concluded that the herb was therapeutically equivalent to and at least as effective as some common antidepressant drugs, while noting that people have better tolerance for the herb.

The director of the study that evaluated St. John's wort asserts that there is no convincing proof to support the botanical's use for any type of depression, though he acknowledges that other studies say it works (news article, April 18). Indeed, several well-designed clinical analyses have studied St. John's wort for its actions on mild to moderate depression and have concluded that the herb was therapeutically equivalent to and at least as effective as some common antidepressant drugs, while noting that people have better tolerance for the herb.

The study's director dismisses as coincidental the finding that more patients taking St. John's wort recovered fully from major depression than those receiving placebos. In fact, this further suggests St. John's wort's value and cries out for further scientific evaluation.
MICHAEL MCGUFFIN President, American Herbal Products Association Silver Spring, Md., April 19, 2001
